medical_history.chief_complaint: Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient had been in his usual state of health until 9 months before admission, when weakness and anorexia developed. Three months before admission, episodes of abdominal discomfort recurred with anorexia and a 10-kg weight loss. Three weeks before admission, the patient experienced diffuse, crampy abdominal pain, nausea worsening after eating, and increased frequency of formed stools. One week before admission, intermittent bilious nonbloody emesis developed, with nausea and abdominal pain worsening the night before admission. The patient reported leg swelling of three weeks' duration and chronic constipation, with a recent increase in stool frequency without overt diarrhea.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Twelve years earlier, the patient sustained multiple fractures in an accident, complicated by nonunion of the left iliac wing and a persistent intestinal hernia. Four years prior, a neurofibroma of the jejunum was resected after presenting with small-bowel obstruction due to S. stercoralis infection.
medical_history.social_history: The patient was born in a Caribbean country, immigrated to the U.S. 25 years ago, and returned to his native country only once, one month before admission. He lived alone, was divorced, had three children, and was unable to work due to a pelvic fracture. The patient did not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs.
